docs.lead_paragraph: You know you need to exercise more, but there's always next week, or the week after. To entice you to stop procrastinating, your company or insurer might soon reward you for wearing a fitness device to track your steps, heart rate and more.

headline.main: Let Your Boss Track Your Fitness, Get an Apple Watch
headline.print_headline: Let Your Boss Track Your Fitness, Get an Apple Watch

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who scored a major victory in a series of Super Tuesday nominating contests, has been criticized by some in his party for being vague on policy specifics and heavy on rhetoric.

headline.main: Factbox-Build a Giant Wall, Cut Education Department. What a President Trump Would Do
headline.print_headline: Factbox-Build a Giant Wall, Cut Education Department. What a President Trump Would Do

docs.lead_paragraph: The insurgent presidential bids of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have roused Americans who are angry and anxious about an economy they feel has left them behind.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court says state officials can't force certain health insurers to turn over reams of data revealing how much they pay for medical claims.

headline.main: High Court Limits State Power to Gather Health Care Data
headline.print_headline: High Court Limits State Power to Gather Health Care Data

docs.snippet: The Supreme Court says state officials can't force certain health insurers to turn over reams of data revealing how much they pay for medical claims.

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, Panasonic Corp. has shaped Japanese corporate tradition — be it morning exercise routines or lifetime employment. But don't hold your breath waiting for other Asian businesses to emulate its latest policy announcement: Recognizing same-sex partnerships.

headline.main: Panasonic Recognition of Same-Sex Marriage an Isolated Move
headline.print_headline: Panasonic Recognition of Same-Sex Marriage an Isolated Move

docs.lead_paragraph: Many drug makers exclusively sell one-size-fits-all vials, meaning patients pay thousands for medicine they are never given, researchers say.

headline.main: Waste in Cancer Drugs Costs $3 Billion a Year, a Study Says
headline.print_headline: Researchers Describe Costly Waste in Cancer Drugs

docs.abstract: Study by Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center researchers in BMJ contends Medicare and private health insurers waste almost $3 billion annually buying cancer drugs that are discarded; says many drug makers distribute drugs in vials that contain too many pills for most patients.
docs.snippet: Many drug makers exclusively sell one-size-fits-all vials, meaning patients pay thousands for medicine they are never given, researchers say.
